awd_titl_txt: RAPID: 2018 Hurricane Season -- Assessing the Role of Antecedent Land State on Hurricane Post-landfall Rainfall
awd_abstract_narration:
Hurricane Florence dropped an extraordinary amount of rainfall on parts of the eastern United States, particularly in coastal North Carolina.  It has been theorized that wet land conditions can provide a moisture feedback that sustains landfalling hurricanes and tropical storms.  The research team will collect data and perform analyses to determine whether this mechanism played a role in the progression of Florence and how it may impact other tropical systems.  The end goal of the research is to improve the forecasts of landfalling hurricanes and the various hazards they pose.  The project will also help to train the next generation of scientists.

This rapid-response award will seek to determine the role of land-surface change during a tropical cyclone landfall on resultant rainfall characteristics.  Hurricane Florence will serve as a case study to address the so-called "Brown Ocean Effect" where wet land provides moisture feedback to sustain landfalling tropical systems.  In this project, the researchers will develop an observational analysis of rainfall and land state during the Florence time period, develop a synthesis of the antecedent and post-landfall land conditions with a focus on the moisture transport and rainfall/water budget, conduct numerical experiments using WRF to test the hypothesis regarding the role of antecedent land state in affecting the inland rainfall from Florence, and compare Hurricane Florence to other similar systems to help refine the conceptual processes involved.  The time-sensitivity of the project lies with the collection of datasets and the distribution of analyses to the scientific community and collaborators from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hurricane Florence was expected to be a typical Atlantic coast, a relatively low intensity hurricane to make landfall off the Carolinas in 2018. However, the hurricane went on to create extensive flooding, and has been the focus of this investigation. The project hypothesizes that the availability of unusually wet soil conditions before the hurricane made landfall, creates the a  moisture source for the storm to maintain its intensity and rainfall potential post landfall. This soil moisture - hurricane rainfall effect is sometimes referred to as 'Brown Ocean' effect. Such 'brown ocean' cases are relatively rare, and hence this project undertook an analysis of the meteorological and hydrodynamic features associated with the antecedent as well as post-landfall conditions. 

The project undertook five activities. The first concerned assessing the rainfall that occurred from the hurricane. This was conducted using different satellite, insitu, and reanalysis products, The second was the synthesis of the antecedent and postlandfall land conditions related to the Florence track. For this satellite as well as a land data assimilation system based on soil moisture fields were developed and used.  The third activity was a weather research and forecast (WRF) model based numerical experimental activity. In this the  WRF based experiments (control and if-then synthesis).were conducted. The fourth task was extending the study results to other cases. Because of the pandemic, the project activities were delayed but provided a serendipitous opportunity to study additional storms along the Texas/ Gulf Coast (Harvey), and Indian Ocean/Bay of Bengal area. The results from these experiments were used in classroom for teaching and conducting projects. The research topic was also used in developing different dissertation chapters for  five Ph.D. students. 

Project results have also been presented at the AMS an AGU conferences, and results have been summarized in peer-reviewed publications. 

Some of the key findings are that rainfall from the hurricane systems is a difficult term to quantify and there is considerable variability and uncertainty depending on which datasets, sensors or locations the rainfall data are being analyzed. A better metric for hurricane rainfall concerns the flux and total volume of the rainfall for a given region. Second, a signature for the unusual rain potential  from hurricanes such as Florence can be found in the prelandfall soil moisture state. The results showed two possible land memory datasets one to three week before landfall. That means, by reviewing the soil moisture conditions 1 to 3 week prior to landfall if it is found to be wetter than normal there is a higher likelihood of the hurricane having higher than normal rainfall and flooding post landfall. These results will need to be tested with additional storms and cases in the future; however, just as the warm oceans provide a clue for high tropical storm activity, the wet (and warm) land state 1 to 3 week before landfall can provide information about heavier than normal rains.
